item.title: Bāla’y-balan
item.description: An Ottoman constructed language World-famous constructed languages range from Zamenhof’s Esperanto to Tolkien’s Quenya to hobbyist “ conlangs”, but isn’t it surprising to learn that centuries before them, an Ottoman in Egypt created his own language and that a thorough grammar and lexicon survives to this day?

item.title: Mount Mountain Mountain
item.description: An Ottoman Turkish tautology Wikipedia has an article on a place called Pendle Hill, noteworthy, perhaps, mainly for being a triple tautology: The name “Pendle Hill” combines the words for hill from three different languages … In the 13th century it was called Pennul or Penhul, apparently from the Cumbric pen and Old English hyll, both meaning “hill”.
